Since I already mentioned Aspect Oriented Programming, I guess a way to tes=
t private methods would be using "Priviledged Aspects" in AspectJ, but I do=
n't think it's viable reply for an urgent situation. I am not using aspects=
 in productions, just experimenting at the moment...

...
	Leaving importan=
t information to comments, docs etc is extremely dangerous! I suggest you c=
heck out refactoring    >	cataloguewww.refactoring.com ("Comments lie, code=
 does not") and how refactoring community treats comments: either you 	don'=
t need them  so you eliminate them or you make code out of them. Similar th=
ing goes for documentation that is 	trying to explain code.
	Making testing=
 influence your design decision is an example of very testing-biased paradi=
gm, but this should not 	conflict  with basic premises of OO, like most of =
new usefull paradigms don't (for example AOP does not make you change 	OO p=
rinciples, it builds on them).
subject: RE: [junit] Re: How to test private methods, its urgent
